title: 106_hr4275
content:
The Act is titled the "Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area and Black Ridge Canyons Wilderness Act of 2000". It includes findings and purposes for the conservation area and wilderness. The Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area and Black Ridge Canyons Wilderness Act of 2000 aims to protect and enhance certain areas in the Grand Valley in Mesa County, Colorado, and Grand County, Utah. These areas, including Black Ridge, Ruby Canyons, Rabbit Valley, and Black Ridge Canyons Wilderness Study Area, offer unique scenic, recreational, paleontological, and wildlife resources that are publicly used for various activities and are worthy of additional protection. The purpose of the Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area and Black Ridge Canyons Wilderness Act of 2000 is to conserve, protect, and enhance the unique geological, cultural, paleontological, natural, scientific, recreational, environmental, biological, wilderness, wildlife education, and scenic resources of the public lands in Colorado and Utah for present and future generations. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Conservation Area - Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area
(2) Council - Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area Advisory Council
(3) Management plan - plan developed for the Conservation Area
(4) Map - map entitled "Proposed Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area and Black Ridge Canyons Wilderness Area"
(5) Secretary - Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management
(6) Wilderness - Black Ridge Canyons Wilderness The Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area is established in Colorado and Utah, consisting of approximately 122,300 acres of public land. The Black Ridge Canyons Wilderness, comprising about 75,550 acres in Colorado and Utah, is designated as wilderness. Management of these areas is outlined. The Secretary manages the Conservation Area to conserve resources and comply with relevant laws. Only approved uses are allowed, and all federal land within the area is withdrawn from public land laws. The Conservation Area is managed to conserve resources and comply with laws. Motorized vehicle use is restricted to designated roads and trails until a management plan is in place. The Conservation Area restricts motor vehicle use to designated roads and trails until a management plan is in place. Wilderness areas designated by this Act will be managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act. The Wilderness Act's effective date is referenced in this Act. Hunting, trapping, and fishing are allowed in the Conservation Area and Wilderness according to US and state laws. Regulations may be issued for area and time closures by wildlife authorities. The Wilderness Act allows hunting, trapping, and fishing in the Conservation Area and Wilderness, with regulations for area and time closures for public safety. Grazing in these areas is administered according to Bureau of Land Management laws and guidelines specified in the Wilderness Act. The Secretary must develop a management plan for the long-term protection and management of the Conservation Area and Wilderness within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should outline appropriate land uses, consider study findings, and ensure continued management of specific sites. The management plan for the Conservation Area and Wilderness must consider historical community involvement, the Ruby Canyon/Black Ridge Integrated Resource Management Plan, and allow only recreational or consistent uses on public lands near the Colorado River. Congress does not intend for buffer zones. The Congress does not intend for buffer zones around the Conservation Area or Wilderness. The Secretary may acquire non-federally owned land within the boundaries only through purchase, exchange, or donation. Land acquired shall be managed as part of the Conservation Area or Wilderness. The Secretary may establish interpretive facilities to protect resources in designated wilderness areas. Congress acknowledges the importance of water rights in wilderness areas with limited water resource facilities upstream. The Act designates wilderness lands not suitable for water resource development and emphasizes alternative management for protection. No water rights are reserved for national conservation or wilderness areas under this Act. The Act does not affect existing water rights in Colorado, does not set a precedent for future conservation areas, and does not impact interstate water compacts. The Secretary must follow Colorado water law for new water rights in the Conservation Area and Wilderness. New projects related to water resource facilities in the Conservation Area and Wilderness are defined, excluding those for livestock grazing. The Act prohibits funding, assisting, authorizing, or issuing licenses or permits for development by the President or any other US officer, employee, or agent, unless specified otherwise. The Act prohibits the development of new water resource facilities within the designated wilderness area. Existing water resource facilities within the boundaries of the Wilderness are not affected. The Conservation Area and Wilderness do not include any part of the Colorado River up to the 100-year high water mark. The Secretary's authority to manage recreational uses on the Colorado River is not affected by the Act. The Act withdraws Federal Government-owned lands along the Colorado River from various forms of entry, appropriation, and disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. SEC. 7. MAPS AND LEGAL DESCRIPTIONS. The Secretary must submit a Map and legal description of the Conservation Area and Wilderness to Congress, with the same force and effect as if included in the Act. Copies will be available for public inspection in specified Bureau of Land Management offices. The Map and legal description of the Conservation Area and Wilderness must be submitted to Congress by the Secretary, with the Map controlling in case of any discrepancies. SEC. 8. ADVISORY COUNCIL. The Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area Advisory Council is established by the Secretary to advise on the management plan and budget for the Conservation Area and Wilderness. The Council consists of 10 members appointed by the Secretary, including representation from Mesa County Commission and grazing allotment permittees. The Colorado Canyons National Conservation Area Advisory Council consists of 10 members appointed by the Secretary, including representation from Mesa County Commission and grazing allotment permittees. The Council includes members with recognized backgrounds related to the purposes and interests of stakeholders affected by the planning and management of the Conservation Area and Wilderness. SEC. 9. PUBLIC ACCESS. The Secretary will allow private landowners access to inholdings in the Conservation Area and Wilderness. Public right of access, including commercial vehicles, will continue to be allowed to Glade Park, Colorado.
